description: This app implements various actions that can be carried out on an AD server

actions.description: Validate the asset configuration for connectivity. This action logs into the device to check the connection and credentials

actions.verbose:
The action supports the following formats as input for username:
  • Simple user name format, for example, test_user (sAMAccountName in AD nomenclature)
  • Email address, for example, test_user@corp.contoso.com (userPrincipalName)
  • Distinguished name format, for example, CN=Test User,CN=Users,DC=corp,DC=contoso,DC=com (distinguishedName)
  • Domain\user_name, for example, Corp\test_user

The action supports the following formats as input for username:
  • Simple user name format, for example, test_user (sAMAccountName in AD nomenclature)
  • Email address, for example, test_user@corp.contoso.com (userPrincipalName)
  • Distinguished name format, for example, CN=Test User,CN=Users,DC=corp,DC=contoso,DC=com (distinguishedName)
  • Domain\user_name, for example, Corp\test_user

actions.description: Get the groups that the user is a member of

username.description: Username (to get groups it belongs to)

actions.verbose:
The action supports the following formats as input for username:
  • Simple user name format, for example, test_user (sAMAccountName in AD nomenclature)
  • Email address, for example, test_user@corp.contoso.com (userPrincipalName)
  • Distinguished name format, for example, CN=Test User,CN=Users,DC=corp,DC=contoso,DC=com (distinguishedName)
  • Domain\user_name, for example, Corp\test_user

actions.description: Change the OU of a computer/system
Set the value of an attribute of a computer/system
Gets the attributes of a user

username.description: Username or Attribute value to match

example_values: State: Disabled, Bad password count: 0, Last logon: 10/23/2018 07:51:41 AM UTC, Password last set: 10/22/2018 11:59:55 AM UTC
State: Enabled, Bad password count: 0, Last logon: 10/23/2018 11:43:04 AM UTC, Password last set: 10/23/2018 11:37:12 AM UTC

actions.verbose:
By default, useraccountcontrol, badpwdcount, pwdlastset and lastlogon fields are fetched along with the mentioned fields. If one or more or all the mentioned fields are invalid, the action will still pass and will display the default fields' values.
The action supports the following formats as input for username:
  • Simple user name format, for example, test_user (sAMAccountName in AD nomenclature)
  • Email address, for example, test_user@corp.contoso.com (userPrincipalName)
  • Distinguished name format, for example, CN=Test User,CN=Users,DC=corp,DC=contoso,DC=com (distinguishedName)
  • Domain\user_name, for example, Corp\test_user
In addition to the above formats and attributes that are matched against, the action also supports matching against an arbitrary attribute, the name of which can be specified in the attribute parameter. For example, to match a user with an employeeID of 10001, set the attribute parameter as employeeID and the username parameter as 10001. An error is reported if the attribute (employeeID in this example) is not found on the LDAP server. More than one user matching is also reported as an error. Please see the ldap_app playbook in the community repo for examples.

actions.description: Gets the attributes of a computer/system

hostname.description: Hostname to query the attributes of

example_values: State: Enabled, Bad password count: 0, Last logon: Never, Password last set: 10/22/2018 12:25:40 PM UTC

actions.verbose: By default, operatingsystem, operatingsystemversion, operatingsystemservicepack, useraccountcontrol, badpwdcount, pwdlastset and lastlogon fields are fetched along with the mentioned fields. If one or more or all the mentioned fields are invalid, the action will still pass and will display the default fields' values.

actions.description: Set the password of a user
actions.verbose:
Note that a user currently logged on will stay logged in. The LDAP server may refuse to accept the password unless the connection is over SSL.

Exercise caution when using this Action. The password may be kept and logged in clear text.

actions.description: Force the user to change the password at the next logon

username.description: Username to enforce 'change password at next logon'

example_values: User 'change password at next logon' enforced

actions.verbose: Once the password is reset, the user is required to login and enter the new password interactively. Therefore auto logins (from applications) will fail.

object_name.description: Object name to query the users of

object_class.description: Object class to query the users of

all_users.description: Get All Users (other params are ignored if set)

actions.verbose:
Use this action to get a list of users. Only users that have email addresses will be returned. If the all_users parameter is set to True, the action will list all users in the enterprise and ignore the object_name and object_class parameters. To list users that belong to a specific group, organizationalUnit or container (known as objects), set the all_users parameter to False and the object_name and object_class (both required in this case) parameters to the required values.
A list of object classes is supplied, one of which the user may choose as the value for the object_class parameter, these are:
  • container
  • organizationalUnit
  • group
When executing the action from a playbook, the author can look up arbitrary object classes by supplying the desired class as a string for the object_class parameter.
The action will first query the system for the dn of the object (using the name and class). The action will fail if an object with the specified object_name belonging to the specified object_class is not found. If the object_class equals "group" then the returned group will be used to populate a query filter that returns all users with a memberOf attribute equal to the full dn of the group with that name. If the object_class is any string other than "group" (such as "container" or "organizationalUnit") then the dn returned from the first query will be used as the base_dn of the User query.
Some examples:
  • To find all users in an Organizational Unit(OU) named UsersOU
    all_users: False
    object_name: UsersOu
    object_class: organizationalUnit
  • To find all users in a Container named Users (Default container found in most AD installations)
    all_users: False
    object_name: Users
    object_class: container
  • To find all users in the group named Enterprise Admins (one of the most powerful default AD groups)
    all_users: False
    object_name: Enterprise Admins
    object_class: group
  • To find all users in the complete enterprise
    all_users: True

name: LDAP
